Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Characterization of Translation Silencing Complexes During oskar mRNA Transport and Localization: Trans-acting ZFactors, RNAi and RNA Decay in the Drosophila oocyte

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: Eukaryotes use a wide range of mechanisms to regulate gene expression. Of particular significance is the transport of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) to particular locations within cells where they are translated in a spatially controlled manner. Processes that depend on the correct spatial and temporal localization of different mRNA transcripts include asymmetric cell division and the establishment of body axes during early development. Many different factors (proteins or other RNAs) can associate with each transcript to ensure its export from the nucleus and its transport to the correct location in the cell. These dynamic interactions between mRNAs and proteins are best studied by visualization of individual mRNA:protein (mRNP) complexes in living cells. Using Drosophila melanogaster as the model developmental system, this project aims to decipher the dynamic composition of a key mRNA transcript that governs axial body patterning during oogenesis. The specific objectives include:

1) To co-visualize specific mRNA transcripts and the protein factors that bind to them to inhibit their translation into proteins while they are being transported to their target sites in living egg chambers.
2) To determine whether small regulatory RNAs (microRNAs) that are predicted to bind to this transcript repress its translation to make protein during its transport in oogenesis.
3) To establish which components of the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway target the mRNPs to specialized cytoplasmic regions for storage or decay. An integrated suite of molecular, genetic, biochemical, biophysical and advanced imaging approaches will be applied to complete these objectives.

Completion of this project will increase our understanding of the mechanisms by which spatio-temporal gene expression is achieved, especially the interactions of RNA-transport machinery with cellular components responsible for RNAi, RNA storage and RNA turnover in living cells.

Broader Impact: This project will provide undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to apply innovative fluorescence imaging techniques to address important biological questions using a powerful genetic model system. The PI will actively recruit, mentor and encourage students from groups underrepresented in the sciences to work on the project, and serve as a role model for young female scientists. The PI will continue to improve and expand an existing course in advanced fluorescence microscopy that she has developed at Hunter College. Her hands-on approach to teaching life sciences and her use of visualization tools to reveal the intricacies of biological pathways, enable students to understand and connect with science beyond textbooks. The educational framework of this project is designed so that all students, regardless of cultural background, will gain valuable experience that will prepare them for demanding graduate programs, post-doctoral positions and the large number of jobs that require experience in biotechnology and handling of model organisms. Moreover, this project will raise the scientific literacy of the public via presentations by the PI and her students of research results at local forums such at New York Academy of Sciences and CUNY Science Caf√©.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This proposal described studies aimed to decipher the composition of mRNPs and to examine the spatio-temporal requirements of several trans-acting factors involved in post-transcriptional control of transported mRNAs during Drosophila melanogaster oogenesis, an established developmental model system. The project focuses on oskar mRNA, one of the key transcripts that governs axis specification during fruit fly development. It is one of the best-studied mRNAs for both its complex life cycle and for its unique role in the germ plasm, which is a specialized cytoplasm at the posterior pole that is required for germ cell formation. The specific objectives addressed are: 1) co-visualization of oskar mRNA and the trans-acting factors involved in its translational repression during mRNA transport at mid-oogenesis, 2) identification of bicoid mRNA-targeting microRNAs and assessment of their role in the silencing of bicoid’s translation and 3) establishment of which components of the RNAi pathway target oskar mRNP to P-bodies for storage or RNA turnover via Staufen-mediated decay. 

A summary of our results are as follows:

1) The dynamic involvement of several proteins (i.e. Cup, Me31B, Bruno, Barentsz, Squid, eIF4E) that have been implicated in the translational regulation of oskar mRNA were addressed. Factors tagged with a fluorescent protein were co-visualized with oskar mRNA, utilizing oskar-specific molecular beacons and single-molecule probes (Stellaris™ FISH probes). We elucidated the distinct steps that occur when these factors associate with the transcript, and we discerned the locations where this process failed in the absence of these factors.

 

2) Based on preliminary data obtained from in silico and in vitro experiments to identify miRNAs that may target bicoid mRNA during oogenesis, a candidate miRNA has been selected, miR-305. We examined bicoid translational regulation in vivo by cloning a gfp-bcd transgene to generate a new fly line. After confirming normal Bcd protein expression from this transgene, we crossed this transgenic line with a miR-305 homozygous KO line. Surprisingly, we did not observe altered timing of bicoid mRNA translation. This finding indicates that loss of miR-305 activity is not sufficient to prematurely activate bicoid mRNA translational in the egg chamber; miR-305 may be acting redundantly with other translational repressor proteins or contribute a very subtle degree to the translational repression of bicoid mRNA. However, we found that overexpression of bicoid mRNA causes its premature translation in the egg chamber, showing that translation repression for bicoid mRNA can be abolished during oogenesis.

 

3) To address whether RNAi pathway proteins (Armi, Aub and Ago1) associate with oskar mRNA and direct it to processing bodies (P bodies), Drosophila RNA storage regions in the cytoplasm, fluorecently-tagged proteins and oskar-specific molecular beacons were co-visualized in real time. Taken together with work published concerning mammalian Staufen and its RNA decay pathway partner Upf1, we assessed their roles on maternal mRNA stability during oogenesis.

In Year 3, we began to address the recruitment of another mRNA that is targeted to
P-bodies, drongo, and whose localization is also altered in the RNAi pathway mutants. We have paralleled the studies for oskar and further explored the mRNA transport process during oogenesis, by using drongo-specific molecular beacons and Stellaris™ FISH probes. We found that similar to Oskar, Drongo is prematurely translated when expression of Me31B is reduced.

Our ability to track mRNP particles in live tissue has resolved important details of the dynamically orchestrated relationship between various proteins and transported mRNAs and provide insight about the interconnected and interdependent processes of RNA transport, silencing and storage, localization and translation activation, and turnover and decay. The ability to visualize these dynamic associations in real time over long periods has far-reaching implications beyond cell biology research, including viral replication, cellular differentiation, and tumor formation.

 

Broader Impacts:

This award provided undergraduate and graduate students with opportunities to do research with an excellent model system, and enabled them to learn innovative fluorescence imaging techniques. Hunter College is a minority serving institution in New York City. Students from underrepresented groups were enrolled in the microscopy course taught by the PI, entitled "Laboratory in Fine Cell Structure" where they were able to experience hands-on science and conduct independent projects.
